Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Multi-Objective Layout Optimization for Multi-Chip Power Electronic Modules

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in semiconductor materials such as silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (GaN) have led to substantial advances in power devices and are now positioned to dominate the next generation of power electronics replacing silicon devices. This project focuses on design automation software for the automatic layout of power electronic modules. The market share of GaN devices is expected to reach a staggering $15.6 billion by 2022 mainly due to the growing demands in the power and energy sector, the communication infrastructure sector, and the power electronics market. SiC power devices are also expected to grow at equally impressive rates. These new power devices are expected to reduce overall energy conversion losses resulting in an annual savings in the tens of billions of dollars in the US alone. A high-efficiency and green energy infrastructure is vital for reducing overall expenditures and reducing carbon footprint in the environment. These new technologies demand more package level integration to achieve low inductance, balanced impedances, and appropriate thermal management to realize the high performance and long life they promise. The expected outcome from this research effort is a software tool incorporating advanced algorithms that will improve design productivity for engineers while simultaneously enhancing performance and reliability of multi-chip power modules in an analogous way that modern design tools ensure the same for integrated circuitry (IC). Design tools in the IC industry have played an indispensable role in the tremendous advances in consumer electronics worldwide. The power electronics that this tool will impact can be found in all types of applications such as data centers, electric vehicles, trains, airplanes, the electric power grid, and motor drives of all types such as heating and air conditioning units.

A team of academic researchers and experienced industrial developers of electronic design automation (EDA) tools will focus on the models and algorithms of PowerSynth, a power module layout synthesis tool. Preliminary findings indicate a need for guaranteeing that power module designs, in particular those that switch at frequencies in the hundreds of kHz, conform to EMI/EMC standards. Further, industrial feedback with respect to those early findings indicate that manufacturability is a first order concern in cost reduction and successful market introduction of wide bandgap power electronics. Electronic packaging must be carefully considered for both performance and reliability. The goals of this research are to create an optimization-driven method for producing the geometrical layouts of multi-chip power modules (MCPMs) that account for the simultaneous electrical, thermal and mechanical issues that can adversely impact performance and reliability of the electronics. Advances in electrical parasitics modeling, thermal modeling, mechanical stress/strain modeling, and optimization algorithms are all expected as part of the project roadmap. These advances will culminate in a software tool that can synthesize geometrical layouts that minimize and balance electrical parasitics, manage thermal distribution in-package, and mitigate mechanical stresses that sacrifice module integrity. Finally, reliability analyses will form the basis for quantifiable manufacturability metrics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaboration between the University of Arkansas and ANSYS to develop the mathematical models and framework necessary to quickly generate and optimize multi-chip power module (MCPM) layouts. MCPMs are the basic building blocks of most power electronic systems such as those in transporation and electric grid applications. By integrating power switching devices with their drive, control, and protection circuitry, MCPMs decrease the size, cost, and complexity of power electronics systems while increasing their reliability. However, the physical integration of these components into one package means that a designer must carefully balance tradeoffs in electrical performance with the demands placed by thermal management and its impact on mechanical reliability. Traditionally, this involved several design iterations prior to prototyping using accurate, but time-consuming simulation software. Further compounding the issue is that the electrical, thermal, and mechanical aspects of a design are often at odds with each other require separate analysis tools.

PowerSynth is a design tool being developed at the University of Arkansas that seeks to address these issues and reduce the number of iterations in the design cycle of new MCPMs. This is accomplished by employing reduced-order models for electrical and thermal performance metrics within a multi-objective optimization framework. These reduced order models allow for the computation of electrical parasitics and device junction temperatures orders of magnitude faster than conventional simulation. Furthermore, the optimization framework employs a genetic algorithm that can rapidly generate MCPM layouts and evaluate them. The results of this optimization are numerous candidate solutions that are presented to the designer on a Pareto frontier of design tradeoffs from which they can select and export a chosen solution to various commercial simulation software packages for further analysis.

Throughout the course of this project, several key milestones were reached that have helped PowerSynth grow to become a more powerful and comprehensive tool. These include the incorporation of a manufacturer design kit (MDK) enabled PowerSynth to more efficiently optimize MCPM layouts by accounting for real-world fabrication capabilities and limitations. This resulted in the optimizer only producing manufacturable designs and was the topic of an undergraduate honors thesis. Testing these results was another goal of this project. This included comparing the electrical and thermal models used in PowerSynth with results from both simulation and physical measurement. In each case the PowerSynth results were within 10% of those from simulation and measurement while computing hundreds of times faster than the current software tools.

The final portion of this project focused on further expanding the electrical modeling capabilities of PowerSynth from beyond parasitics estimation. A new electrical model was introduced that better captured mutual and coupling effects among the conductors within the MCPM along with current density estimation. Additionally, a conducted electromagnetic interference (EMI) model was developed. This allowed for EMI-aware design to be accomplished during optimization, leading to layouts with decreased propensity towards noisy emissions.

Findings from this project, as well as detailed explanations of the models developed and methods used, have been the topic of six conference papers and one journal article published within the last four years. In addition, several live demonstrations of PowerSynth and seminars regarding its functionality have been presented to our collaborators, partners, and other interested parties.
